summary: The concept of "federal government," categorized under executive power and public service, is redirected to the preferred term "central government" within EU legal and regulatory frameworks. In the context of the European Union, the central government refers to the authoritative body that exercises executive functions and oversees public administration at the national level. This structure is pivotal for implementing EU directives and regulations, ensuring compliance with overarching legal standards. The central government plays a crucial role in maintaining the rule of law and facilitating cooperation among member states, thereby reinforcing the integrity of the EU's legal order and public service delivery.
